pageData.text: In this exercise, images of <button class='glossary-text'>angiosperm</button> plant tissues are used to characterize and differentiate traditionally classified <button class='glossary-text'>monocot</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>dicot</button> specimens. This study card set is a valuable tool to improve observational skills and introduce the subject of plant histology. A field component is also included to further apply knowledge acquired from the study cards.

text: Identify plant stems, roots, <button class='glossary-text'>flowers</button>, seeds, and leaves from magnified images.
Distinguish between traditionally classified <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button> using specified characteristics.
Identify plant tissues from magnified images.

pageData.text: Plants have amazing adaptations. For many flowering plants, it is essential to attract pollinators. Many plants have evolved color patterns that attract bees and other pollinators. Some plants have evolved to rely on scavenging insects by employing less pleasant kinds of attractants.

Carrion <button class='glossary-text'>flowers</button> (also known as corpse flowers) have evolved traits that are reminiscent of dead bodies. When in bloom, they smell like rotting flesh. Some species take corpse mimicry one step further by featuring red, brown, and purple coloration. These characteristics attract scavenging flies, flesh flies, house flies, and beetles as pollinators. Scientists do not yet know exactly how these plants produce their unique scent, but they do know it contains smelly sulfide and amine compounds<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.
Reference1A. Brunning. (2017). The Blooming of a Corpse Flower. Scientific American. https://www.americanscientist.org/article/the-blooming-of-a-corpse-flower

pageData.desc: A carrion flower on which sits a fly.
pageData.altText: A carrion flower on which sits a fly.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Spermatophytes</button> are a large group of organisms comprised of plants that contain seeds. Within this group are the <button class='glossary-text'>angiosperms</button>, or flowering plants, which are of the most diverse group of extant plants, containing over 250,000 species which are classified into approximately 450 families. This diverse group of plants is clearly united by a suite of the following <button class='glossary-text'>synapomorphies</button>, or shared, derived characters:

text: Double fertilization, which leads to the formation of an endosperm
<button class='glossary-text'>Phloem</button> tissue composed of sieve tubes and companion cells

pageData.text: Traditionally, angiosperms were subdivided into two assemblages: <button class='glossary-text'>monocotyledons</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>dicotyledons</button>. This classification scheme was based on the attribute that monocotyledons have one <button class='glossary-text'>cotyledon</button>, or seed leaf, and dicotyledons have two. These two groups are commonly referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button>. However, evidence has accumulated that indicates that angiosperms do not fall into these two major groups.

Monocotyledons and dicotyledons are named for the number of embryonic leaves they each have. Monocotyledons (“one cotyledon”) have one embryonic seed leaf (cotyledon), and dicotyledons (“two cotyledons”) have two seed leaves (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Comparison of the two embryonic leaves of a dicot with the single embryonic leaf of a monocot
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Comparison of the two embryonic leaves of a dicot with the single embryonic leaf of a monocot

pageData.text: While <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button> are not <button class='glossary-text'>monophyletic</button> (a group consisting of an ancestral species and all of its descendants—Figure 2), <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button> are a distinct, strongly supported group. Non-molecular phylogenetic studies of monocots have identified 13 accepted <button class='glossary-text'>synapomorphies</button>, including a single <button class='glossary-text'>cotyledon</button>, parallel-veined leaves, sieve cell plastids with several cuneate protein crystals, scattered <button class='glossary-text'>vascular bundles</button> in the stem, and an adventitious root system. It was long suspected that the dicots, as traditionally recognized, represent multiple evolutionary lineages, and the <button class='glossary-text'>paraphyly</button> (consisting of a group descended from a common ancestor but missing one or more monophyletic groups) of dicots, based on molecular data, prevents their recognition in current classifications. Many dicots, however, are found in the eudicot clade. Eudicots, are a clade strongly supported by molecular data, and account for the bulk of <button class='glossary-text'>angiosperm</button> species.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Phylogenetic tree of plants with monocots labeled as monophyletic, and dicots labeled as paraphyletic
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Phylogenetic tree of plants with monocots labeled as monophyletic, and dicots labeled as paraphyletic

pageData.text: Despite the phylogenetic transformations, there are still valid structural and histological components from the traditionally recognized <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button> that are worth studying.

<button class='glossary-text'>Angiosperm</button> roots contain a <button class='glossary-text'>stele</button> (Figure 3), or center of the plant structure. The stele contains <button class='glossary-text'>xylem</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>phloem</button>, the vascular tissue of the root. In monocots, the vascular tissue is arranged in a ring around the central area of the stem, known as a <button class='glossary-text'>pith</button> (Figure 3), while in dicots, it is star-shaped with no pith. Surrounding the stele in both types of angiosperms is a <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button> made of <button class='glossary-text'>parenchyma</button>, or living, cells. The roots of monocots are fibrous and thin and spread out below the soil surface. Dicots have a taproot system, in which one main root penetrates deeply into the soil to anchor the plant and locate water.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Labeled cross section of an angiosperm root showing the stele and the pith in the center, surrounded by the cortex.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Labeled cross section of an angiosperm root showing the stele and the pith in the center, surrounded by the cortex.

pageData.text: Stems support the aboveground structures of the plant, transport food and nutrients throughout the plant, store food, and function in photosynthesis. Stems also contain vascular tissue, but it is not located in the center of the structure, as it is in roots. In , the form a ring around the outer edge of the stem, surrounding the , which is made of cells (Figure 4, left). In some dicots, the central pith will break down, and the stem becomes hollow. Outside of the vascular bundles lies the hard outer . cells are located within the vascular bundle, toward the center of the stem, just above the . The is found at the lower end of the vascular bundle, toward the outside of the stem, and is separated from the xylem by a layer of cells called the . The outer ring is the hard outer cortex of the stem. have neither pith nor cortex; rather, vascular bundles are scattered throughout the stem (Figure 4, right). Xylem, which transports water from the plant’s roots to the leaves, is located toward the top of the vascular bundle, and phloem, which transports sugars, minerals, and hormones throughout the plant, is located toward the lower end of the bundle. The bundles are outlined with sclerenchyma cells around the xylem and phloem, which provide stiffness and strength to the plants.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Comparison of stem cross sections from a monocot and a dicot. At the center of the dicot stem is the pith. Vascular bundles are in a ring around the pith. In the monocot, vasuclar bundles are randomly dispersed.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Comparison of stem cross sections from a monocot and a dicot. At the center of the dicot stem is the pith. Vascular bundles are in a ring around the pith. In the monocot, vasuclar bundles are randomly dispersed.

pageData.question: What is a major difference in the roots of monocots and dicots?

options.text: Dicots have a fibrous and thin root system that is shallow.
Monocots have roots with symbiotic associations to soil fungi.
Monocots have separate roots systems for acquiring water and nutrients.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The roots of monocots are fibrous and thin and spread out below the soil surface, while dicots have a taproot system.

pageData.question: Which of the following are the transport structures in plant roots and stems?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Xylem and phloem transport water, nutrients and hormones through a plant.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Traditionally, angiosperms were subdivided into two assemblages: monocotyledons and dicotyledons. This classification scheme was based on the attribute that monocotyledons have one cotyledon, or seed leaf, and dicotyledons have two. These two groups are commonly referred to as monocots and dicots. However, evidence has accumulated that indicates that angiosperms do not fall into these two major groups. Angiosperm roots contain a stele, the center of the plant structure. The stele contains xylem and phloem, the vascular tissue of the root. In monocots, the vascular tissue is arranged in a ring around the central area of the stem, known as a pith (Figure 3), while in dicots, it is star-shaped with no pith. Surrounding the stele in both types of angiosperms is a cortex made of parenchyma. The roots of monocots are fibrous and thin and spread out below the soil surface, while dicots have a taproot system that anchors the plant and locates water.

img.alt: Figure 3: Labeled cross section of an angiosperm root showing the stele and the pith in the center, surrounded by the cortex.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Traditionally, angiosperms were subdivided into two assemblages: monocotyledons and dicotyledons. This classification scheme was based on the attribute that monocotyledons have one cotyledon, or seed leaf, and dicotyledons have two. These two groups are commonly referred to as monocots and dicots. However, evidence has accumulated that indicates that angiosperms do not fall into these two major groups. Angiosperm roots contain a stele, the center of the plant structure. The stele contains xylem and phloem, the vascular tissue of the root. In monocots, the vascular tissue is arranged in a ring around the central area of the stem, known as a pith (Figure 3), while in dicots, it is star-shaped with no pith. Surrounding the stele in both types of angiosperms is a cortex made of parenchyma. The roots of monocots are fibrous and thin and spread out below the soil surface, while dicots have a taproot system that anchors the plant and locates water.

img.alt: Figure 3: Labeled cross section of an angiosperm root showing the stele and the pith in the center, surrounded by the cortex.

pageData.text: Leaves contain an upper epidermis, mesophyll, and lower epidermis. Within the upper and lower epidermises are <button class='glossary-text'>stomata</button>, structures controlled by <button class='glossary-text'>guard cells</button>, which open and close to allow gas exchange and control water loss within the plant. The <button class='glossary-text'>vascular bundles</button> in the leaf are found within the mesophyll layer. <button class='glossary-text'>Xylem</button> cells have thick walls that stain red and are generally found on the upper portion of the vascular bundle. Water that is lost through the leaves is constantly replaced by water transported by the xylem. <button class='glossary-text'>Phloem</button> cells appear smaller and have thinner walls that stain less. They are generally found on the bottom of the vascular bundle.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Comparison of the vascular bundles in the cross sections of a monocot leaf and a dicot leaf. The vascular bundle is in a central vein of the dicot  while the vascular bundles are along the outsides of the monocot leaf.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Comparison of the vascular bundles in the cross sections of a monocot leaf and a dicot leaf. The vascular bundle is in a central vein of the dicot  while the vascular bundles are along the outsides of the monocot leaf.

pageData.text: The largest <button class='glossary-text'>vascular bundle</button> is the mid-vein of the leaf. These vascular bundles are evenly spaced throughout <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button>. Leaves of most monocots have parallel <button class='glossary-text'>venation</button>, which means that the veins are in a longitudinal parallel arrangement (Figure 6, right). The mesophyll of <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button> is divided into the <button class='glossary-text'>upper palisade mesophyll</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>lower spongy mesophyll</button>. The palisade mesophyll contains chloroplasts and is the primary site of photosynthesis. The spongy mesophyll contains air spaces that allow for gas movement. The vascular bundles within these layers are unevenly spaced throughout the dicot.
Dicots have netted venation, which means that the veins are arranged in a net-like pattern across and down the leaf (Figure 6, left).

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Comparison of parallel leaf veins of the monocot and net-like leaf veins of the dicot.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Comparison of parallel leaf veins of the monocot and net-like leaf veins of the dicot.

pageData.question: What controls the opening and closing of the stomata?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Within the upper and lower epidermises are stomata that are controlled by guard cells, which open and close to allow gas exchange and control water loss within the plant.

pageData.question: What important function does xylem perform?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water that is lost through the stomata in the leaves is constantly replaced by water transported by the xylem.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leaves contain an upper epidermis, mesophyll, and lower epidermis. Within the upper and lower epidermises are stomata, structures controlled by guard cells, which open and close to allow gas exchange and control water loss within the plant. The vascular bundles in the leaf are found within the mesophyll layer. Xylem cells have thick walls that stain red and are generally found on the upper portion of the vascular bundle. Xylem transports water and nutrients from the plant soil interface to stems and leaves and provides mechanical support and storage.  Phloem cells appear smaller and have thinner walls that stain less. Phloem transports sugars, minerals, and hormones throughout the plant. They are generally found on the bottom of the vascular bundle. The largest vascular bundle is the mid-vein of the leaf. These vascular bundles are evenly spaced throughout monocots.

img.alt: Figure 6: Comparison of parallel leaf veins of the monocot and net-like leaf veins of the dicot.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leaves contain an upper epidermis, mesophyll, and lower epidermis. Within the upper and lower epidermises are stomata, structures controlled by guard cells, which open and close to allow gas exchange and control water loss within the plant. The vascular bundles in the leaf are found within the mesophyll layer. Xylem cells have thick walls that stain red and are generally found on the upper portion of the vascular bundle. Xylem transports water and nutrients from the plant soil interface to stems and leaves and provides mechanical support and storage.  Phloem cells appear smaller and have thinner walls that stain less. Phloem transports sugars, minerals, and hormones throughout the plant. They are generally found on the bottom of the vascular bundle. The largest vascular bundle is the mid-vein of the leaf. These vascular bundles are evenly spaced throughout monocots.

img.alt: Figure 6: Comparison of parallel leaf veins of the monocot and net-like leaf veins of the dicot.

pageData.text: A , the site of sexual reproduction in a plant, is a complex structure composed of numerous parts. In the lily, the outermost whorl, or circle, is made up of three , which look very similar to the . Sepals are leaf-like structures that encircle the flower stem and enclose the bud. The petals create the inner whorl. The petals are also leaf-like and are arranged in a circle around the top of the stem, within the sepals. The , the male reproductive part of the flower, consists of the filament and . The anther is responsible for producing , which contains the male gamete in the plant. In the lily (Figure 7), just medial to the petals, is the whorl of six anthers, which contains pollen. Each flower contains multiple stamens.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Labeled cross section of the base of a lily flower, showing the pistil in the center, the anthers ringing the pistil. The petals surround the anthers and the sepal is outside that.
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Labeled cross section of the base of a lily flower, showing the pistil in the center, the anthers ringing the pistil. The petals surround the anthers and the sepal is outside that.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>pistil</button> is the <button class='glossary-text'>flower’s</button> female reproductive structure. It contains the stigma, style, and ovary. The ovary houses the ovules, which contain the flower’s egg cells. In the lily, the innermost section is the ovary, which encases the egg cells. There is only one pistil in each flower. The parts in <button class='glossary-text'>monocot</button> flowers are typically found in multiples of three, and those in <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button> are in multiples of four or five (Figure 8).

A seed is a reproductive unit that results from the union of an egg (ovule) and a sperm (<button class='glossary-text'>pollen</button>). The seed contains an embryonic plant and a supply of stored food within a tough, protective seed coat. Some seeds can remain dormant for long periods. As the seed germinates, the embryo develops into a seedling. <button class='glossary-text'>Angiosperms</button> produce seeds that are derived from the ovary of a flower. The seed-containing structure is a fruit. The fruit helps protect the seed(s), and in many cases, helps in seed dispersal. Many of the foods we eat, such as apples, peaches, and tomatoes, are the ripened ovaries and seeds of angiosperms. These fruits and seeds develop from the pollinated flowers of the plants.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Comparison of the two embryonic leaves of a dicot with the single embryonic leaf of a monocot
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Comparison of the two embryonic leaves of a dicot with the single embryonic leaf of a monocot

pageData.question: Where are the male gametes in a plant found?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The anther is responsible for producing pollen, which contains the male gamete in the plant.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures of a flower is best described as female?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The stigma is part of the pistil, the flower’s female reproductive structure.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A flower, the site of sexual reproduction in a plant, is a complex structure composed of numerous parts. In the lily, the outermost whorl (circle) is made up of three sepals, which look very similar to the petals. Sepals are leaf-like structures that encircle the flower stem and enclose the bud. The petals create the inner whorl. The petals are also leaf-like and are arranged in a circle around the top of the stem, within the sepals. The stamen, the male reproductive part of the flower, consists of the filament and anther. The anther is responsible for producing pollen, which contains the male gamete of the plant. In the lily, just medial to the petals, is the whorl of six anthers, which contains pollen. Each flower contains multiple stamens. The pistil is the flower’s female reproductive structure. It contains the stigma, style, and ovary. The ovary houses the ovules, which contain the flower’s egg cells. In the lily, the innermost section is the ovary, which encases the egg cells. There is only one pistil in each flower. A seed is a reproductive unit that results from the union of an egg (ovule) and a sperm (pollen).

img.alt: Figure 7: Labeled cross section of the base of a lily flower, showing the pistil in the center, the anthers ringing the pistil. The petals surround the anthers and the sepal is outside that.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, identify the plant part on a study card, then classify the plant as a monocot or dicot. Repeat this for the 12 study cards. In Activity 2, find an outdoor location with native plants. Then, photograph a plant specimen and identify a plant part. Classify the plant as a monocot or dicot. Repeat this photographing and classification process until 5 plants have been observed.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: A plant is infected with a disease that causes its xylem tissues to break down. Which of the following is most likely to occur as a result of this disease?

options.text: The plant will not get enough water to survive.
The plant will not be able to communicate with nearby plants.
The plant will become susceptible to other infections.
The plant will perform excessive amounts of photosynthesis.
The plant will be unable to reproduce.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT a shared derived character of angiosperms?

options.text: phloem tissue composed of sieve tubes and companion cells

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the tissue layers of a leaf?

options.text: outer whorl, pith, cortex, inner whorl

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes an apple as a plant structure?
Which term refers to an embryonic leaf?
Which of the following is a dicot characteristic?

options.text: vascular bundles scattered throughout the stem
flower parts in multiples of three
root vascular tissue arranged in a ring around a central area of pith.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a monocot characteristic?

options.text: flower parts in multiples of three
vascular bundles arranged in a ring around the outer edge of the stem
star-shaped arrangement of vascular tissue in the center of the root

assestmentData.question: Angiosperms are traditionally subdivided into which groups?

In Activity 1, you will examine the images on the study cards, identify each plant part, and classify each plant as a <button class='glossary-text'>monocot</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>dicot</button>.
Examine the image on the study card labeled “#1.”
Determine the part of the plant you are examining (, stem, root, etc.), and record your answer in Data Table 1.
Identify this plant as either a or , and record your answer in Data Table 1.
Provide reasoning for your answer to question 3 in Data Table 1.
Repeat steps 1–4 with each of the study cards.

In Activity 2, you will examine <button class='glossary-text'>angiosperms</button> in a natural location and take photos of specimens. You will identify the features of each plant and classify the plants as <button class='glossary-text'>monocots</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>dicots</button>.
Go outdoors or to a nearby park, botanical garden, etc., and examine native <button class='glossary-text'>angiosperms</button> (flowering plants).

data.title: Angiosperm
data.content: A flowering plant

data.title: Anther
data.content: The part of a stamen responsible for producing pollen

data.title: Cambium
data.content: The actively dividing layer of cells that lies between, and gives rise to, the secondary xylem and phloem

data.title: Cortex
data.content: The tissue surrounding the stele that is made up of living cells

data.title: Cotyledon
data.content: A seed leaf

data.title: Dicot (dicotyledon)
data.content: One of two traditional subgroups of angiosperms; its classification was based on its having two cotyledons but now the group is considered paraphyletic

data.title: Flower
data.content: The site of sexual reproduction in angiosperms made up of a complex structure of numerous parts

data.title: Guard cells
data.content: Paired cells in the epidermis of a plant that control the opening and closing of a stoma

data.title: Lower spongy mesophyll
data.content: A type of mesophyll tissue in dicots that contains air spaces that allow for gas movement

data.title: Monocot (monocotyledon)
data.content: One of two traditional subgroups of angiosperms; its classification was based on their single cotyledon but now includes a host of other synapomorphies

data.title: Monophyletic
data.content: Describes a taxonomic group consisting of an ancestral species and all of its descendants

data.title: Paraphyly
data.content: A taxonomic group descended from a common ancestor but missing one or more monophyletic groups

data.title: Parenchyma
data.content: Plant tissue made up of living cells

data.title: Petal
data.content: A leaf-like structure that can attract pollinators; petals are arranged in a circle around the top of the stem, within the sepals

data.title: Phloem
data.content: Vascular tissue that transports sugars, minerals, and hormones throughout the plant; is located toward the lower end of a vascular bundle

data.title: Pistil
data.content: The female reproductive structure of a flower; it contains the stigma, style, and ovary

data.title: Pith
data.content: The central area of a plant

data.title: Pollen
data.content: Granule-like structures produced by the anther and which contain the male gamete in the plant.

data.title: Sclerenchyma
data.content: Plant tissue that provides stiffness and strength to the plant

data.title: Sepal
data.content: A leaf-like structure that can be found in the outermost circle of a flower; sepals encircle the flower stem and enclose the bud

data.title: Spermatophyte
data.content: A member of a large group of organisms comprised of plants that contain seeds

data.title: Stamen
data.content: The male reproductive part of the flower; it consists of a filament and an anther

data.title: Stele
data.content: The center of the plant structure consisting of the vascular tissue (xylem and phloem) and associated supporting tissue

data.title: Stomata
data.content: Structures controlled by guard cells, which open and close to allow gas exchange and control water loss within the plant; singular, stoma

data.title: Synapomorphy
data.content: A character or trait that is shared by two or more taxonomic groups and is derived through evolution from a common ancestral form

data.title: Upper palisade mesophyll
data.content: A type of mesophyll tissue in dicots that contains chloroplasts and is the primary site of photosynthesis

data.title: Vascular bundle
data.content: A group of xylem and phloem that run through plant stems

data.title: Venation
data.content: The arrangement of veins

data.title: Xylem
data.content: Vascular tissue that transports water from the plant’s roots to the leaves; it is located toward the top of a vascular bundle
